metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (automatic weather station of Zhangye wetland station, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Zhangye wetland station from January 1 to December 31, 2021. The site (100.4464° E, 38.9751° N) was located on a wetland (reed surface) in Zhangye National Wetland Park, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1460 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45AC; 5 and 10 m, north), wind speed profile (03002; 5 and 10 m, north), wind direction profile (03002; 10 m, north), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 10 m), four-component radiometer (CNR1; 6 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (109ss-L; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2 and -0.4 m), and four photosynthetically active radiation (PQS-1; two above the plants, 6 m, south, one vertically downward and one vertically upward; two below the plants, 0.25 m, south, one vertically downward and one vertically upward).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m and Ta_10 m; RH_5 m and RH_10 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_5 m and Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, and Ts_20 cm) (℃), on the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_U_up and PAR_U_down) (μmol/ (s m^-2)), and below the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_D_up and PAR_D_down) (μmol/ (s m^-2)).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2021-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Provide an example of how datasets from oasis–desert systems can be used to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange.
Example.Answer: Datasets from oasis–desert systems, which include long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, can be used to understand these exchanges by offering insights into the interactions between oasis and desert ecosystems. Such datasets, collected from multiple meteorological stations, are essential for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Definition.Question: What does 'comprehensive observation network' mean in the context of meteorological and ecological data collection?
Definition.Answer: In the context of meteorological and ecological data collection, a 'comprehensive observation network' refers to a system of interconnected observation stations that collect a wide range of data related to surface processes, such as meteorological factors, radiation, and soil parameters. This network enables the study and monitoring of diverse environmental and climatic conditions across a specified area, such as the middle reaches of the Heihe River Basin.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'quality control' in the process of data collection and processing in meteorological studies?
Definition.Answer: In meteorological studies, 'quality control' is crucial for ensuring the accuracy and reliability of collected data. It involves processes such as detecting and marking missing data, removing duplicate records, filtering out data that exceed physical or instrumental limits, and highlighting questionable data. These steps help maintain the integrity and usability of the dataset for further analysis and research.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in observational parameters between the automatic meteorological station at the Zhangye Wetland Station and the oasis–desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: The Zhangye Wetland Station records parameters such as air temperature, humidity, pressure, precipitation, wind speed and direction, radiation, and soil temperature at various depths. The oasis–desert systems also include long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, as well as hydrometeorological data, indicating a broader set of parameters related to fluxes and additional auxiliary data in comparison to the meteorological focus of the Zhangye Station.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying environmental challenges can be inferred from the long-term patterns of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The long-term patterns of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange may indicate challenges such as ecological degradation, drying of water bodies, and desertification, especially in arid inland river basins. These patterns highlight the need for sustainable management to balance oasis and desert systems and maintain ecological stability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in maintaining data accuracy and quality in meteorological observations in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological degradation, such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms, which can impact data accuracy and quality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it essential to implement long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which are significant for maintaining the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for using both artificial and natural oasis–desert systems in observational studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Using both artificial and natural oasis–desert systems helps to understand the interactions and balance between these ecosystems, which is vital for sustainable oasis development and achieving goals like carbon neutrality.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on data quality and reliability when implementing a comprehensive observation network with various sensor types in an arid region?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing a comprehensive observation network with various sensor types in an arid region can enhance the depth and breadth of environmental data, potentially improving understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. However, it may also introduce challenges in data quality and reliability due to the harsh environmental conditions that can affect sensor performance, requiring robust data processing and quality control measures to ensure accurate and consistent datasets.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of long-term observation datasets from oasis–desert systems influence the strategies for sustainable oasis development?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating long-term observation datasets from oasis–desert systems provides a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions. This information can significantly influence strategies for sustainable oasis development by informing actions that maintain ecological stability and socioeconomic development, ultimately supporting the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in the context of dataset creation for oasis–desert interactions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial to achieve sustainable oasis development, support ecological security, and promote socioeconomic stability. Understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these systems helps in achieving carbon peaking and neutrality goals.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the underlying goals for establishing and utilizing observational datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals include gaining a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges to recognize oasis–desert interactions, protect ecological stability, and support socioeconomic development, thereby contributing to sustainable oasis development and global carbon cycle management.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why are long-term observations considered indispensable for understanding oasis–desert ecosystems in research datasets?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial as they provide comprehensive data necessary for understanding the basic characteristics and interactions within oasis–desert ecosystems, which is essential for ecological stability, carbon balance, and supporting sustainable development goals.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to ensure the quality and accuracy of meteorological data collected from automatic weather stations in the context of oasis–desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data processing and quality control procedures involve ensuring daily data completeness, removing duplicate records, deleting data beyond physical or instrumental limits, and marking questionable data. The date and time are formatted consistently within the dataset.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are observational datasets structured and what methodologies are employed to collect energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in arid inland river basins?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Observational datasets include long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data collected using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. Auxiliary hydrometeorological data are collected via automatic weather stations at 10-minute intervals, supplemented with vegetation and soil parameters.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental setups are necessary for capturing soil temperature and radiation profiles in an oasis–desert ecosystem, and how are these instruments typically positioned?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil temperature probes are installed at various depths, including the surface and underground at multiple depths (e.g., 2cm, 4cm, etc.), while radiation instruments are set up at specific heights and orientations, such as 6m high facing south for radiation measurement. Instruments include soil heat flux plates and various radiation sensors.

Enablement.Question: What observational technologies enable the comprehensive monitoring of meteorological and surface processes in wetland ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The use of automatic weather stations equipped with various sensors, such as those for air temperature, relative humidity, pressure, rain, wind speed and direction, radiation, and soil parameters, allows for comprehensive monitoring of meteorological and surface processes in wetland ecosystems.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or resources are necessary for the long-term observation of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems require a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations, equipped with eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations, as well as the availability of auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in maintaining long-term data collection in oasis–desert systems, and how might these challenges impact the quality or continuity of datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face challenges such as ecological environment degradation, drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These factors could potentially impact the quality or continuity of datasets by affecting observational conditions and data accuracy.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be important to include a comprehensive suite of hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters in datasets for oasis–desert systems, and what outcomes are expected from such an approach?
Expectation.Answer: Including a comprehensive suite of hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters is crucial for a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is significant for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, protecting ecological stability, and supporting socioeconomic development of oases.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think the current data collection methods are in capturing the interactions between oasis and desert systems, considering the challenges faced in arid and semi-arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection methods, which include long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, as well as hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations, are crucial for understanding oasis-desert interactions. These methods are effective in capturing detailed and continuous data needed to assess ecological stability and support sustainable development goals in these regions.

Assertion.Answer: The challenges in maintaining a comprehensive observational dataset in oasis-desert ecosystems include dealing with ecological environment degradation such as drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These factors, especially prevalent in inland river basins, can hinder long-term data collection and affect the quality of observational datasets.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how datasets related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas are structured and managed for research purposes.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas are structured to include data on energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, hydrometeorological data, and vegetation and soil parameters. These datasets are collected from a network of stations, including superstations and ordinary stations, and are managed through a process of data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. They are often made freely available for research purposes through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the data processing and quality control procedures used in collecting meteorological and environmental data in arid and semi-arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure involves ensuring a consistent number of data entries per day (144, recorded every 10 minutes), marking missing data with a placeholder (-6999), removing duplicate recordings, and deleting data that exceeds physical or instrumental limits. Any questionable data is highlighted, and the format for date and time is standardized. The overall process includes data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing, with a focus on maintaining data integrity and accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the challenges faced in collecting long-term environmental data in inland river basins of arid and semi-arid areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in collecting long-term environmental data in these regions include the degradation of ecological environments, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are particularly prevalent in inland river basins along the Silk Road, like the Tarim River basin, Aral Sea basin, and Lake Urmia basin.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential data sources or repositories that can provide datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems.
Request/Directive.Answer: The National Tibetan Plateau Data Center is a potential source for datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems. The datasets include observations from land surface flux and meteorological stations established since 2012 in the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin, which is located in the arid regions of western China.
